Then he sighed deeply. Pointing to a house, they said: “This is your ancestors’ dwelling.” He wept silently. Pointing to a mound, they said: “This is your ancestors’ grave.” The man could not restrain his sobs. His companions burst into laughter, saying: “We were only jesting with you—this is but the land of Jin.” The man was stunned.

When he at last reached Yan and truly saw the city and village shrine of Yan, truly saw his ancestors’ dwelling and grave, his sorrow diminished.

---

**Part Four**

Confucius was at leisure in his chamber when Zigong entered to attend him, his countenance troubled. Zigong dared not ask, but upon leaving, he told Yan Hui. Yan Hui took up his zither and sang. Hearing this, Confucius summoned Yan Hui back and asked: “Why do you alone find joy?”

Yan Hui replied: “Why does the Master alone bear sorrow?”

Confucius said: “First speak your own mind.”

Yan Hui said: “I once heard the Master say: ‘He who delights in the Dao and knows fate is therefore without sorrow’—this is why I find joy.”

Confucius, his expression darkening, asked: “Did I truly say such a thing? You have misunderstood. That was my teaching of former days; let my words of today be taken as correct. You know only that delighting in the Dao and knowing fate brings freedom from sorrow, but you do not know that delighting in the Dao and knowing fate entails a sorrow greater still.

Now I will tell you the truth: to cultivate the self, to accept poverty or prosperity, to know that past and future are not one’s own, to banish disturbance from the heart—this is what you call delighting in the Dao and knowing fate without sorrow. Formerly, I studied the *Book of Songs* and *Book of Documents*, rectified rites and music, intending to govern all under heaven and leave a legacy for future generations—not merely to cultivate the self or govern the state of Lu. Yet the rulers and ministers of Lu daily lose their proper order; benevolence and righteousness grow ever weaker, human nature ever more shallow. If the Dao cannot prevail in a single state or a single generation, how can it prevail in all under heaven or for ages to come? I first realized that the *Book of Songs*, *Book of Documents*, rites, and music could not save the world from disorder, yet I did not know the means to reform it—this is the sorrow of one who delights in the Dao and knows fate.

Though even so, I have grasped it now. The joy and knowledge of which I speak are not what the ancients called joy and knowledge. Without joy, without knowledge—this is true joy, true knowledge. Thus there is nothing not joyful, nothing not known, nothing not sorrowful, nothing not done. Why then abandon the *Book of Songs*, *Book of Documents*, rites, and music? Why seek to reform them?”

Yan Hui bowed northward and said: “I too have grasped it.” He went out and told Zigong. Zigong stood bewildered, lost in thought. Returning home, he brooded for seven days without sleep or food, until his frame was reduced to bone. Yan Hui went again to enlighten him, whereupon he returned to Confucius’ gate, playing the zither and chanting the classics all day without cease.

---

A minister of Chen, on a mission to Lu, sought a private audience with the house of Shusun. Shusun said: “In our state there is a sage.”

The minister asked: “Is it not Kong Qiu?”

Shusun replied: “It is. How did you know he is a sage?”

Shusun said: “I once heard Yan Hui say: ‘Kong Qiu can still the mind and employ the body.’”

The minister of Chen said: “In our state, too, there is a sage—did you not know? Who is this sage?”

Shusun asked: “Of whom do you speak?”

The minister said: “Among the disciples of Lao Dan, there is one named Kang Cangzi who has attained Lao Dan’s Dao. He can see with his ears and hear with his eyes.”

The Lord of Lu, hearing this, was greatly astonished and sent his highest minister with rich gifts to invite him. Kang Cangzi accepted the summons and came. The Lord of Lu, speaking humbly, sought his instruction.

Kang Cangzi said: “The reports of me are false. I can see and hear without using ears and eyes, but I cannot reverse their functions.”

The Lord of Lu said: “This is even more extraordinary! What is the nature of your Dao? I earnestly wish to hear it.”

Kang Cangzi said: “My body aligns with my mind, my mind with my qi, my qi with my spirit, my spirit with the formless. If there is the slightest presence of something, the faintest sound, whether far away at the ends of the earth or near at hand between my brows, whatever comes to disturb me, I will surely know it. Yet I do not know whether this awareness comes from my seven orifices and four limbs, or from the knowledge of my heart and six viscera—it simply knows itself.”

The Lord of Lu was overjoyed. Later, he told Confucius, who smiled but did not answer.

---

The Grand Steward of Shang visited Confucius and asked: “Is Qiu a sage?”

Confucius said: “How would Qiu dare claim sagacity? Yet Qiu is one of broad learning and many attainments.”

The Grand Steward asked: “Were the Three Kings sages?”

Confucius said: “The Three Kings were skilled in employing wisdom and courage—whether they were sages, Qiu does not know.”

The Grand Steward asked: “Were the Five Emperors sages?”

Confucius said: “The Five Emperors were skilled in employing benevolence and righteousness—whether they were sages, Qiu does not know.”

The Grand Steward asked: “Were the Three Sovereigns sages?”

Confucius said: “The Three Sovereigns were skilled in adapting to the times—whether they were sages, Qiu does not know.”

The Grand Steward, greatly startled, said: “Then who is a sage?”

Confucius, his expression shifting after a pause, said: “Among the people of the West, there is one who may be a sage. He does not govern, yet there is no disorder; he does not speak, yet is trusted; he does not transform, yet things follow their course. So vast is he that the people cannot name him. I suspect he may be a sage, but I do not know whether he truly is a sage—or truly is not.”

The Grand Steward fell silent, pondering to himself: “Kong Qiu deceives me!”

---

Zixia asked Confucius: “What sort of man is Yan Hui?”

Confucius said: “Hui’s benevolence surpasses my own.”

Zixia asked: “What sort of man is Zigong?”

Confucius said: “Ci’s eloquence surpasses my own.”

Zixia asked: “What sort of man is Zilu?”

Confucius said: “You’s courage surpasses my own.”

Zixia asked: “What sort of man is Zizhang?”

Confucius said: “Shi’s dignity surpasses my own.”

Zixia rose from his mat and asked: “Then why do these four serve you?”

Confucius said: “Sit. I will tell you.”

chunks.original_text: 夫回能仁而不能反，赐能辩而不能讷，由能勇而不能怯，师能庄而不能同。 兼四子之有以易吾，吾弗许也。 此其所以事吾而不贰也。 子列子既师壶丘子林，友伯昏瞀人，乃居南郭。 从之处者，日数而不及。 虽然，子列子亦微焉，朝朝相与辩，无不闻。 而与南郭子连墙二十年，不相谒请，相遇於道，目若不相见者，门之徒役以为子列子与南郭子有敌不疑。 有自楚来者，问子列子曰：先生与南郭子奚敌？ 子列子曰：南郭子貌充心虚，耳无闻，目无见，口无言，心无知，形无惕。 往将奚为？ 虽然，试与汝偕往。 阅弟子四十人同行，见南郭子，果若欺魄焉，而不可与接。 顾视子列子，形神不相偶，而不可与群。 南郭子俄而指子列子之弟子未行者与言，衎衎若专直而在雄者。 子列子徒骇之，反舍，咸有疑色。 子列子曰：得意者无言，进知者亦无言。 用无言为言亦言，无知为知亦知。 无言与不言，无知与不知，亦言亦知。 亦无所不言，亦无所不知； 亦无所言，亦无所知。 如斯而已。 汝奚妄骇哉？

Hui may possess benevolence, yet he cannot return to simplicity; Ci may possess eloquence, yet he cannot be reticent; You may possess courage, yet he cannot be timid; Shi may possess dignity, yet he cannot be yielding. Were I to exchange all that I have for the strengths of these four, I would not consent. This is why they serve me without divided loyalty.

Master Liezi had already taken Huqiu Zilin as his teacher and befriended Bohun Maoren, then dwelled in the southern outskirts. Those who followed him daily grew in number yet never surpassed him. Nevertheless, Liezi was still somewhat lacking: each morning, they debated together, and there was nothing he had not heard. Yet for twenty years, he shared a wall with Nan Guozi, never paying visits or sending invitations. When they met on the road, their eyes seemed not to see each other. The servants at Liezi’s gate assumed there must be enmity between him and Nan Guozi.

A man arrived from Chu and asked Liezi: “Master, what enmity do you have with Nan Guozi?”

Liezi said: “Nan Guozi’s appearance is full, yet his mind is empty; his ears hear nothing, his eyes see nothing, his mouth speaks nothing, his mind knows nothing, his form shows no agitation. What could one do with him? Nevertheless, I will go with you.”

He gathered forty disciples and set out together. When they saw Nan Guozi, he indeed appeared like a disembodied spirit, impossible to engage. Looking back at Liezi, his form and spirit were not in harmony, and he could not blend in with the group. Suddenly, Nan Guozi pointed to Liezi’s disciples who had not yet spoken and addressed them, his manner cheerful and forthright, like a leader among men.

Liezi’s disciples were astonished. Returning home, they all wore expressions of doubt.

Liezi said: “Those who have attained the Dao speak not; those who advance in knowledge also speak not. To use silence as speech is still speech; to use ignorance as knowledge is still knowledge. Silence and not speaking, ignorance and not knowing—these are also speech and knowledge. They are without anything not spoken, without anything not known; yet also without anything spoken, without anything known. It is simply thus. Why are you so groundlessly astonished?”

chunks.original_text: 子列子学也，三年之后，心不敢念是非，口不敢言利害，始得老商一眄而已。 五年之后，心更念是非，口更言利害，老商始一解颜而笑。 七年之后，从心之所念，更无是非； 从口之所言，更无利害。 夫子始一引吾并席而坐，九年之后，横心之所念，横口之所言，亦不知我之是非利害欤？ 亦不知彼之是非利害欤？ 外内进矣。 而后眼如耳，耳如鼻，鼻如口，口无不同。 心凝形释，骨肉都融。 不觉形之所倚，足之所履，心之所念，言之所藏。 如斯而已。 则理无所隐矣。 初，子列子好游。 壶丘子曰：御寇好游，游何所好？ 列子曰：游之乐所玩无故。 人之游也，观其所见； 我之游也，观其所变。 游乎游乎，未有能辨其游者。 壶丘子曰：御寇之游固与人同欤，而曰固与人异欤？ 凡所见，亦恒见其变。 玩彼物之无故，不知我亦无故。 务外游，不知务内观。 外游者，求备於物； 内观者，取足於身。 取足於身，游之至也； 求备於物，游之不至也。 於是列子终身不出，自以为不知游。 壶丘子曰：游其至乎，至游者，不知所适； 至观者，不知所眂。 物物皆游矣，物物皆观矣，是我之所谓游，是我之所谓观也。 故曰：游其至矣乎。 游其至矣乎。 龙叔谓文挚曰：子之术微矣。 吾有疾，子能已乎？ 文挚曰：唯命所听。 然先言子所病之证。 龙叔曰：吾乡誉不以为荣，国毁不以为辱； 得而不喜，失而弗忧； 视生如死，视富如贫，视人如豕，视吾如人； 处吾之家，如逆旅之舍； 观吾之乡，如戎蛮之国。 凡此众疾#7，爵赏不能劝，刑罚不能威，盛衰、利害不能易，哀乐不能移。 固不可事国君，交亲友，御妻子，制仆隶。 此奚疾哉？ 奚方能已之乎？

Liezi studied for three years, after which his heart dared not entertain thoughts of right and wrong, nor his mouth speak of profit and harm. Only then did Old Shang deign to glance at him once. Five years later, his heart again pondered right and wrong, his mouth again spoke of profit and harm, and only then did Old Shang begin to relax his countenance and smile. After seven years, whatever his heart conceived, there was no longer right or wrong; whatever his mouth uttered, there was no longer profit or harm. Only then did the Master draw him to sit beside him on the same mat. Nine years later, whether his heart wandered or his mouth spoke freely, he knew not whether these were his own right and wrong, profit and harm, or another’s. Inner and outer had advanced as one. Thereafter, his eyes were as ears, his ears as nose, his nose as mouth—all were indistinguishable. His mind congealed, his form dissolved, flesh and bone fused entirely. He no longer sensed what his body leaned against, where his feet trod, what his heart conceived, or what his words concealed. It was simply thus. Then no principle remained hidden.

Earlier, Liezi delighted in wandering. Master Huqiu asked: “Yu Kou delights in wandering—what does he delight in when he wanders?” Liezi replied: “The joy of wandering lies in savoring what has no fixed nature. Others wander to observe what they see; I wander to observe what transforms. Wandering, wandering—none can distinguish this wandering.” Master Huqiu said: “Is Yu Kou’s wandering truly the same as others’, or is it truly different? All that is seen is ever seen in its transformations. To delight in the unfixed nature of things yet not know that I, too, am unfixed—to seek wandering outwardly yet not know to seek inner contemplation—this is the way. The outward wanderer seeks completion in things; the inward observer finds sufficiency in the self. Finding sufficiency in the self is the perfection of wandering; seeking completion in things is its imperfection.” Thereupon, Liezi never left his home again, believing himself ignorant of wandering. Master Huqiu said: “Is this not the perfection of wandering? The perfect wanderer knows not where he goes; the perfect observer knows not what he beholds. All things wander, all things observe—this is what I call wandering, what I call observation. Thus it is said: Is this not the perfection of wandering? Is this not the perfection of wandering?”

Long Shu said to Wen Zhi: “Your art is subtle. I suffer from an affliction—can you cure it?” Wen Zhi replied: “I await your command. But first, tell me the symptoms of your ailment.” Long Shu said: “Praise from my village brings me no honor, slander from my state brings me no shame. Gain does not gladden me, loss does not grieve me. I regard life as death, wealth as poverty, others as swine, and myself as no different from them. Dwelling in my home, I see it as an inn for travelers; viewing my village, I see it as a land of barbarians. All these manifold afflictions—neither rank nor reward can sway me, neither punishment nor threat can intimidate me, neither prosperity nor decline, profit nor harm can alter me, neither sorrow nor joy can move me. Thus, I cannot serve a lord, befriend kin, govern a wife and children, or command servants. What is this affliction? What method can cure it?”

chunks.original_text: 文挚乃命龙叔背明而立。 文挚自后向明而望之。 既而曰：嘻，吾见子之心矣。 方寸之地虚矣，几圣人也。 子心六孔流通，一孔不达。 今以圣智为疾者，或由此乎？ 非吾浅术所能已也。 无所由而常生者，道也； 由生而生，故虽终而不亡，常也； 由生而亡，不幸也。 有所由而常死者，亦道也； 由死而死，故虽未然而自亡者，亦常也； 由死而生，幸也。 故无用而生谓之道，用道得终谓之常； 有所用而死者亦谓之道，用道而得死者亦谓之常。 季梁之死，杨朱望其门而歌； 随梧之死，杨朱抚其尸而哭。 隶人之生，隶人之死，众人且歌，众人且哭。 目将眇者，先睹秋毫； 耳将聋者，先闻蚋飞； 口将爽者，先辨淄渑； 鼻将室者，先觉焦朽； 体将僵者，先亟奔佚； 心将迷者，先识是非。 故物不至者则不反。 郑之圃泽多贤，东里多才。 圃泽之役有伯丰子者，行过东里，遇邓析。 邓析顾其徒而笑曰：为若舞，彼来者奚若？ 其徒曰：所愿知也。 邓析谓伯丰子曰：汝知养养之义乎？ 受人养而不能自养者，犬豕之类也； 养物而物为我用者，人之力也。 使汝之徒食而饱，衣而息，执政之功也。 长幼群聚而为牢籍庖厨之物，奚异犬豕之类乎？ 伯丰子不应。 伯丰子之从者越次而进曰：大夫不闻齐、鲁之多机乎？ 有善治土木者，有善治金革者，有善治声乐者，有善治书数者，有善治军旅者，有善治宗庙者，群才备也。 而无相位者，无能相使者。 而位之者无知，使之者无能，而知之与能为之使焉。 执政者乃吾之所使，子奚矜焉，邓析无以应，目其徒而退。 公仪伯以力闻诸侯，堂溪公言之於周宣王，王备礼以聘之。 公仪伯至。 观形，懦夫也。 宣王心惑而疑曰：女之力何如？ 公仪伯曰：臣之力能折春蠡之股，堪秋蝉之翼。 王作色曰：吾之力者能裂犀兕之革，曳九牛之尾，犹憾以弱。 女折春虱之股，堪秋蝉之翼，而力闻天下，何也？ 公仪伯长息退席，曰：善哉王之问也。 臣敢以实对。
chunks.translated_text:
Then Wen Zhi bade Long Shu stand with his back to the light. Wen Zhi himself stood behind him, facing the light, and gazed at him. After a while, he said: “Ah! Now I see your heart. The square inch of ground within is empty—you are nearly a sage. Your heart has six apertures flowing freely, with only one still blocked. Is it not perhaps from this that those who take sagely wisdom as an affliction arise? This is not something my shallow art can cure.

That which arises without cause and yet is ever-generating is the Dao. That which is generated by generation, though it may end, does not perish—this is constancy. That which is generated yet perishes is misfortune. That which arises with cause and yet is ever-dying is also the Dao. That which dies by death, though it may not yet have come to pass, perishes of itself—this too is constancy. That which dies yet lives is fortune.

Thus, to live without use is called the Dao; to employ the Dao and attain an end is called constancy. To die with use is also called the Dao; to employ the Dao and attain death is also called constancy. When Ji Liang died, Yang Zhu gazed at his gate and sang. When Sui Wu died, Yang Zhu caressed his corpse and wept. The birth of a bondsman, the death of a bondsman—common folk sing, common folk weep.

One whose eyes are about to dim first sees the autumn down; one whose ears are about to deafen first hears the gnat in flight; one whose palate is about to fail first distinguishes the waters of the Zi and the Meng; one whose nose is about to block first detects the scent of charred rot; one whose body is about to stiffen first hastens to flee; one whose heart is about to be deluded first discerns right and wrong. Thus, when a thing does not reach its end, it does not return.

In Zheng, the marshlands of Puze abounded in worthies, and Dongli teemed with talent. During the campaign at Puze, there was a man named Bo Fengzi who, passing through Dongli, encountered Deng Xi. Deng Xi turned to his disciples and laughed, saying: “Let us perform a dance for him. What think you of that one approaching?” His disciples replied: “We would gladly know.” Deng Xi said to Bo Fengzi: “Do you understand the meaning of nourishing and being nourished? To receive nourishment from others yet be unable to nourish oneself is the way of dogs and swine. To nourish things and have them serve one’s use is the power of man. If your followers eat their fill, clothe themselves, and rest, it is the achievement of governance. Yet when the old and young gather in droves to become fodder for the pens and kitchens, how is this different from the way of dogs and swine?”

Bo Fengzi did not respond. One of his followers stepped out of turn and advanced, saying: “Has the Master not heard of the many devices in Qi and Lu? There are those skilled in working earth and wood, those skilled in working metal and leather, those skilled in music, those skilled in writing and calculation, those skilled in military affairs, and those skilled in ancestral rites—all talents are assembled. Yet without one to order their positions, without one to command their abilities, and when the one who orders lacks knowledge, the one who commands lacks ability, then knowledge and ability are made to serve. The one who governs is but one whom we make to serve. Why then do you boast, Deng Xi?” Deng Xi could make no reply; he glared at his disciples and withdrew.

Gongyi Bo was renowned among the feudal lords for his strength. Tangxi Gong spoke of him to King Xuan of Zhou, who prepared gifts and sent an envoy to summon him. When Gongyi Bo arrived and the king observed his form, he saw only a feeble man. Perplexed, King Xuan asked: “What is the measure of your strength?” Gongyi Bo replied: “Your servant’s strength can snap the leg of a spring louse and bear the wing of an autumn cicada.” The king’s expression darkened as he said: “My strength can rend the hide of a rhinoceros or a young buffalo and drag the tails of nine oxen, yet I still regret my weakness. You can snap the leg of a spring louse and bear the wing of an autumn cicada, yet your strength is renowned throughout the world—how can this be?” Gongyi Bo sighed deeply, withdrew from his mat, and said: “Excellent is Your Majesty’s question. I dare speak truly in reply.”

All these manifold afflictions—neither rank nor reward can sway me, neither punishment nor threat can intimidate me, neither prosperity nor decline, profit nor harm can alter me, neither sorrow nor joy can move me. Thus, I cannot serve a lord, befriend kin, govern a wife and children, or command servants. What is this affliction? What method can cure it?”

chunks.original_text: 臣之师有商丘子者，力无敌於天下，而六亲不知，以未尝用其力故也。 臣以死事之。 乃告臣曰：人欲见其所不见，视人所不窥； 欲得其所不得，修人所不为，故学视者先见舆薪，学听者先闻撞钟。 夫有易於内者无难於外。 於外无难，故名不出於一家#8。 今臣之名闻於诸侯，是臣违师之教，显臣之能者也。 然则臣之名不以负其力者也，以能用其力者也，不犹愈於负其力者乎？ 中山公子牟者，魏国之贤公子也。 好与贤人游，不恤国事，而悦赵人公孙龙。 乐正子舆之徒笑之。 公子牟曰：子何笑牟之悦公孙龙也？ 子舆曰：公孙龙之为人也，行无师，学无友，佞给而不中，漫衍而无家，好怪而妄言。 欲惑人之心，屈人之口，与韩檀等肄之。 公子牟变容曰：何子状公孙龙之过欤？ 请闻其实。 子舆曰：吾笑龙之诒孔穿，言善射者能令后镞中前括，发发相及，矢矢相属，前矢造准而无绝落，后矢之括犹衔弦，视之若一焉。 孔穿骇之。 龙曰：此未其妙者。 远蒙之弟子曰鸿超，怒其妻而怖之。 引乌号之弓，綦卫之箭，射其目。 矢来注眸子而眶不睫，矢坠地而尘不扬。 是岂智者之言欤？ 公子牟曰：智者之言固非愚者之所晓。 后镞中前括，钧后於前。 矢注眸子而眶不睫，尽矢之势也。 子何疑焉？ 乐正子舆曰：子，龙之徒，焉得不饰其阙？ 吾又言其尤者。 龙诳魏王曰：有意不心。 有指不至。 有物不尽。 有影不移。 发引千钧。 白马非马。 孤犊未尝有母。 其负类反伦，不可胜言也。 公子牟曰：子不谕至言而以为尤也，尤其在子矣。 夫无意则心同，无指则皆至。 尽物者常有。 影不移者，说在改也。 发引千钧，势至等也。 白马非马，形名离也。 孤犊未尝有母，非孤犊也。 乐正子舆曰：子以公孙龙之鸣#9皆条也。 设令发於余窍，子亦将承之。 公子牟默然良久，告退。 曰：请待余日，更谒子论。 尧治天下五十年，不知天下治欤？ 不治欤？ 不知亿兆之愿戴己欤？ 不愿戴己欤？ 顾问左右，左右不知； 问外朝，外朝不知； 问在野，在野不知。
chunks.translated_text:
My master, a man of Shangqiu named Zi, possessed strength unmatched in the world, yet his kin never knew it, for he never once employed his strength. I served him unto death. He once instructed me: “One who wishes to see what others cannot must train his eyes where others do not look; one who wishes to obtain what others cannot must cultivate what others do not practice. Thus, those who learn to see first perceive a cartload of firewood, and those who learn to hear first catch the tolling of a bell. For one whose inner power is effortless, no outer task is difficult. When no outer task is difficult, his name does not leave even a single household.”

Now my name is known among the feudal lords—this means I have violated my master’s teaching and made my ability conspicuous. Yet my renown does not come from squandering my strength, but from knowing how to use it. Is this not better than squandering it?

The Lord Mou of Zhongshan, a worthy prince of Wei, delighted in the company of worthy men. He neglected state affairs and took pleasure in the company of Gongsun Long, a man of Zhao. The disciples of Le Zhengzi Yu laughed at him. Lord Mou asked: “Why do you laugh at my delight in Gongsun Long?”

Ziyu replied: “Gongsun Long’s character is such that he follows no master, studies with no companions, flatters glibly without substance, rambles aimlessly without a school, and delights in the strange while uttering absurdities. He seeks to bewilder men’s minds and silence their speech, practicing sophistry alongside men like Han Tan.”

Lord Mou’s expression changed as he said: “Why do you describe Gongsun Long’s faults so? Pray tell me the truth.”

Ziyu said: “I laugh at how Long deceived Kong Chuan, saying that a skilled archer could make the rear arrowhead strike the front nock, each shot following the last, each shaft linked to the next, so that the first arrow reaches the target without a single miss, and the nock of the last arrow still rests on the bowstring—appearing as one. Kong Chuan was astonished. Long said: ‘This is not yet the marvel.’ A disciple of Yuan Meng named Hong Chao, enraged at his wife, sought to frighten her. He drew the Wuhao bow and loosed a Qiwei arrow at her eye. The arrow flew straight toward her pupil, yet her eyelid did not blink; the arrow fell to the ground, and not a speck of dust was stirred. Can this truly be the words of a wise man?”

Lord Mou said: “The words of the wise are not understood by fools. The rear arrowhead striking the front nock hooks the later to the earlier. The arrow flying toward the pupil without the eyelid blinking exhausts the arrow’s momentum. Why do you doubt this?”

Le Zhengzi Yu said: “You are a follower of Long—how could you not gloss over his flaws? I shall tell you of his greater absurdities. Long deceived the King of Wei, saying: ‘There is intention without mind. There is pointing without reaching. There is substance without exhaustion. There is shadow without movement. A single hair can draw a thousand jun. A white horse is not a horse. An orphaned calf never had a mother.’ His violations of categories and inversions of logic are too numerous to recount.”

Lord Mou said: “You take profound words as absurdities—your error is greater still. Without intention, minds are the same; without pointing, all things are reached. To exhaust a thing is to possess it always. That a shadow does not move lies in its transformation. A single hair drawing a thousand jun arises from equal force. That a white horse is not a horse comes from the separation of form and name. That an orphaned calf never had a mother means it is not an orphaned calf.”

Le Zhengzi Yu said: “You take all of Gongsun Long’s prattling as reasoned argument. If such words issued from another’s mouth, you would still endorse them.”

Lord Mou fell silent for a long while, then withdrew, saying: “Let me wait for another day to call upon you and discuss this further.”

When Yao ruled the world for fifty years, he did not know whether the world was well governed or not, nor whether the countless people wished to support him or not. He turned to his attendants and asked, but they did not know; he asked the outer court, and they did not know; he asked those in the wilds, and they did not know.

chunks.original_text: 尧乃微服游於康衢，闻童儿谣曰：立我蒸民，莫菲尔极。 不识不知，顺帝之则。 尧喜问曰：谁教尔为此言？ 童儿曰：我闻之大夫。 问大夫。 大夫曰：古诗也。 尧还官，召舜，因禅以天下。 舜不辞而受之。 关尹喜曰：在已无居，形物其着。 其动若水，其静若镜，其应若响，故其道若物者也。 物自违道，道不违物。 善若道者，亦不用耳，亦不用目，亦不用力，亦不用心。 欲若道而用视听形智以求之，弗当矣。 瞻之在前，忽焉在后； 用之弥满六虚，废之莫知、其所。 亦非有心者所能得远，亦非无心者所能得近。 唯默而得之而性成之者得之，知而忘情，能而不为，真知真能也。 发无知，何能情？ 发不能，何能为？ 聚块也，积尘也，虽无为#10而非理也。 汤问第五 殷汤问於夏革曰：古初有物乎？ 夏革曰：古初无物，今恶得物？ 后之人将谓今之无物，可乎？ 殷汤曰：然则物无先后乎？ 夏革曰：物之终始，初无极已。 始或为终，终或为始，恶知其纪？ 然自物之外，自事之先，朕所不知也。 殷汤曰：然则上下八方有极尽乎？ 革曰：不知也。 汤固问。 革曰：无则无极，有则有尽，朕何以知之？ 然无极之外复无无极，无尽之中复无无尽。 无极复无无极，无尽复无无尽。 朕以是知其无极无尽也，而不知其有极有尽也。 汤又问曰：四海之外奚有？ 革曰：犹齐州也。 汤曰：汝奚以实之？ 革曰：朕束行至营，人民犹是也。 问营之东，复犹营也。 西行至豳，人民犹是也。 问豳之西，复犹豳也。 朕以是知四海、四荒、四极之不异是也。 故大小相含，无穷极也。 含万物者，亦如含天地，含万物也，固不穷； 含天地也，故无极。 朕亦焉知天地之表不有大天地者乎？ 亦吾所不知也。 然则天地亦物也。 物有不足，故昔者女娲氏练五色石以补其阙，断鳌之足以立四极。 其后共工氏与颛顼争为帝，怒而触不周之山，折天柱，绝地维； 故天倾西北，日月星辰就焉； 地不满东南，故百川水潦归焉。 汤又问：物有巨细乎？ 有修短乎？ 有同异乎？

Yao then disguised himself and wandered through the bustling thoroughfares, where he heard children singing a rhyme:

*“He raised us, the steaming masses,
No lack in your ultimate measure.
Unknowing, unperceiving,
We follow the Dao of the Lord.”*

Delighted, Yao asked, “Who taught you these words?”
The children replied, “We heard them from a grandee.”
He asked the grandee, who said, “It is an ancient poem.”

Yao returned to his palace, summoned Shun, and thereupon abdicated the world to him. Shun accepted without refusal.

Guan Yinxi said: *“Abiding in nothingness, forms manifest their presence.
Its movement is like water, its stillness like a mirror, its response like an echo—thus is the Dao like things.
Things depart from the Dao; the Dao does not depart from things.
Those who are good at the Dao neither use their ears, nor their eyes, nor their strength, nor their minds.
To seek the Dao through seeing, hearing, form, or knowledge is to miss the mark.
It may seem before you, then suddenly behind; employed, it fills the Six Voids; abandoned, none know its whereabouts.
Neither those with minds can grasp it from afar, nor those without minds draw near.
Only those who silently attain it and nurture it through their nature obtain it—knowing yet forgetting emotion, capable yet not acting, this is true knowledge and true ability.
If one lacks knowledge, how can there be emotion? If one lacks ability, how can there be action?
A clod of earth, a pile of dust—though non-active, it is not the Dao.”*

**Tang’s Fifth Inquiry**
Tang of Yin asked Xia Ge: “In the earliest antiquity, were there things?”
Xia Ge replied: “In the earliest antiquity, there were no things. How could there be things now? Would later generations be right to say there are no things now?”
Tang of Yin said: “Then do things have no before or after?”
Xia Ge said: “The end and beginning of things have no ultimate limit. The beginning may become the end, the end may become the beginning—how can one know their order? Yet beyond things, before events, I do not know.”
Tang of Yin said: “Then do the eight directions and above and below have limits?”
Ge said: “I do not know.”
Tang pressed further.
Ge said: *“Where there is nothing, there is no limit; where there is something, there is an end—how could I know this?
Yet beyond the limitless there is no further limitlessness, within the endless there is no further endlessness.
Limitlessness has no further limitlessness, endlessness has no further endlessness.
From this I know it is limitless and endless, but I do not know that it has limits or ends.”*
Tang asked again: “What lies beyond the four seas?”
Ge said: “The same as the Central States.”
Tang said: “How do you confirm this?”
Ge said: *“I traveled east to Ying, and the people were the same. Asking about east of Ying, it was still like Ying.
I traveled west to Bin, and the people were the same. Asking about west of Bin, it was still like Bin.
From this I know the four seas, the four wastes, the four poles are no different.
Thus the great and small contain one another without end.
One who contains the ten thousand things is like one who contains heaven and earth—containing the ten thousand things, he is not exhausted; containing heaven and earth, he is limitless.
How do I know that beyond heaven and earth there are not greater heavens and earths? This too I do not know.
Yet heaven and earth are also things.
Things are insufficient, so in ancient times Nüwa smelted stones of five colors to mend their gaps, severed the legs of the great turtle to prop up the four poles.
Later, Gonggong contended with Zhuanxu for the throne, and in rage struck Mount Buzhou, breaking the pillar of heaven and severing the cords of earth.
Thus heaven tilted to the northwest, and the sun, moon, and stars moved there; earth was not full in the southeast, so the hundred rivers and floodwaters flowed there.”*
Tang asked again: “Do things have great and small? Long and short? Same and different?”

chunks.original_text: 革曰：渤海之东不知几亿万里，有大壑焉，实惟无底之谷，其下无底，名曰归墟。 八弦九野之水，天汉之流，莫不注之，而无增无臧焉。 其中有五山焉：一曰岱舆，二曰贠峤，三曰方壶； 四曰瀛洲，五曰蓬莱。 其山高下周旋三万里，其顶平处九千里。 山之中间相去七万里，以为邻居焉。 其上台观皆金玉，其上禽兽皆纯缟。 珠玕之树皆丛生，华实皆有滋味，食之皆不老不死。 所居之人皆仙圣之种，一日一夕飞相往来者，不可数焉。 而五山之根无所连着，常随潮波上下往还，不得暂峙焉。 仙圣毒之，诉之於帝。 帝恐流於西极，失群圣之居，乃命禺疆使巨鳌十五举首而戴之。 迭为三番，六万岁一交焉。 五山始峙而不动。 而龙伯之国有大人，举足不盈数步#11而暨五山之所，一钓而连六鳌，合负而趣归其国，灼其骨以数焉。 於是岱舆、贠峤二山流於北极、沉於大海，仙圣之播迁者巨亿计。 帝凭怒，侵减龙伯之国使阨，侵小龙伯之民使短。 至伏羲、神农时，其国人犹数千#12丈。 从中州以东四十万里得僬侥国，人长一尺五寸。 东北极有人名曰静人，长九寸。 荆之南有冥灵者，以五百岁为春，五百岁为秋。 上古有大椿者，以八千岁为春，八千岁为秋。 朽壤之上有菌芝者，生於朝，死於晦。 春夏之月有蠓蚋者，因雨而生，见阳而死。 终发北之北有溟海者，天池也，有鱼焉，其广数千里，其长称焉，其名为鲲。 有鸟焉，其名为鹏，翼若垂天之云，其体称焉。 世岂知有此物哉？ 大禹行而见之，伯益知而名之，夷坚闻而志之。 江浦之间生么虫，其名曰焦螟，群飞而集於蚊睫，弗相触也。 栖宿去来，蚊弗觉也。 离朱、子羽方昼拭訾扬眉而望之，弗见其形； 角虎丑豸文余普弭三切俞、师旷方夜擿耳俛首而听之，弗闻其声。 唯黄帝与容成子居空同之上，同斋三月，心死形废； 徐以神视，块然见之，若嵩山之阿； 徐以气听，砰然闻之，若雷霆之声。

Gé said: East of the Bohai Sea, beyond countless millions of *li*, there lies a great abyss, a bottomless valley indeed, called the Returning Gully. The waters of the Eight Directions and Nine Wilds, the currents of the Celestial River—none fail to pour into it, yet it neither swells nor diminishes.

Within it stand five mountains: the first is called Dàiyú, the second Yuánqiáo, the third Fānghú, the fourth Yíngzhōu, and the fifth Pénglái. Each mountain rises and winds for thirty thousand *li*, its flat summit spanning nine thousand *li*. The distance between their midpoints is seventy thousand *li*, yet they are neighbors. Their terraces and towers are all of gold and jade, their birds and beasts all pure white. Trees of pearl and jade grow in clusters, their blossoms and fruits all rich in flavor; those who eat them never age nor die. The inhabitants are all of the seed of immortals and sages, and those who fly back and forth between them in a single day or night are beyond counting.

Yet the roots of the five mountains had no fixed mooring, drifting ceaselessly with the tides, unable to stand firm for even a moment. The immortals and sages, distressed, appealed to the Emperor. Fearing the mountains would drift to the westernmost reaches and the dwellings of the assembled sages be lost, he commanded Yújiāng to dispatch fifteen giant turtles to lift their heads and bear the mountains aloft. They took turns in three shifts, rotating every sixty thousand years. Thus the five mountains stood firm and unmoving.

Now, in the land of Lóngbó there lived giants whose strides spanned the five mountains in fewer than a dozen steps. One of them cast a line and hooked six of the turtles at once, then carried them back to his country, where he scorched their bones to divine by their cracks. Thereupon the two mountains Dàiyú and Yuánqiáo drifted to the northern pole and sank into the great sea, and the immortals and sages who were displaced numbered in the countless millions. The Emperor, enraged, diminished the land of Lóngbó to straiten it and shrank its people to shorten them. By the time of Fúxī and Shénnóng, its inhabitants still measured several thousand *zhàng* in height.

From the Central States eastward four hundred thousand *li* lies the land of Jiāoyáo, where people stand a foot and a half tall. In the far northeast there are beings called the Tranquil Folk, nine inches in height. South of the Jing region dwell the Dark Numinous Ones, for whom five hundred years make a spring and five hundred years an autumn. In high antiquity there was the Great Chūn Tree, for whom eight thousand years make a spring and eight thousand years an autumn. Upon rotting soil grow fungi and mushrooms that sprout at dawn and wither by dusk. In the months of spring and summer there are midges and gnats that come to life with the rain and die at the sight of the sun.

North of the northernmost reaches lies the Dark Sea, a celestial lake, wherein dwells a fish several thousand *li* in breadth, its length commensurate, called the Kūn. There is also a bird called the Péng, its wings like clouds trailing from the sky, its body in proportion. Does the world know of such creatures? Great Yǔ beheld them in his travels, Bóyì named them in his knowledge, and Yíjiān recorded them in his annals.

Between the riverbanks there breed tiny insects called the Jiāomíng, which swarm and alight upon the lashes of mosquitoes without touching them. They come and go, roost and depart, yet the mosquito remains unaware. Lízhū and Zǐyǔ, in broad daylight, rubbed their eyes and raised their brows to peer, yet could not make out their form. Jiǎohǔ, Chǒuzhì, Wényú, Pǔmǐ, Sānqièyú, and Shī Kuàng, in the dead of night, cupped their ears and bent their heads to listen, yet could not catch their sound. Only the Yellow Emperor and Róngchéngzǐ, dwelling upon Kōngtóng, fasted together for three months, their hearts stilled and bodies forgotten. Then, with their spirit, they gazed slowly and saw them as clearly as the slopes of Mount Sōng; with their *qi*, they listened slowly and heard them as loudly as thunder.

chunks.original_text: 昊、楚之国有大木焉，其名为櫾，碧树而冬生，实丹而味酸。 食其皮汁，已愤厥之疾。 齐州珍之，渡淮而北而化为枳焉。 鴝鹆不踰济，貉踰汶则死矣，地气然也。 虽然，形气异也，性钧已，无相易已，生皆全已，分皆足已。 吾何以识其巨细？ 何以识其修短？ 何以识其同异哉？ 大形、王屋二山，方七百里，高万仞，本在冀州之南，河阳之北。 北山愚公者，年且九十，面山而居。 惩山北之塞，出入之迂也。 聚室而谋，曰：吾与汝毕力平险，指通豫南，达于汉阴，可乎？ 杂然相许。 其妻献疑曰：以君之力，曾不能损魁父之丘，如太形、王屋何？ 且焉置土石？ 杂曰：投诸渤海之尾，隐土之北。 遂率子孙荷担者三夫，叩石垦壤，箕畚运於渤海之尾。 邻人京城氏之孀妻有遗男，始龄，跳往助之。 寒暑易节，始一反焉。
chunks.translated_text:
In the lands of Hào and Chǔ, there stands a great tree called the *yòu*, its verdant branches bearing fruit in winter. Its berries are crimson and tart. Drinking the sap of its bark cures the malady of *fènjué*. The people of Qízhōu prize it, yet when carried north across the Huái River, it transforms into the *zhǐ*. The myna bird does not cross the Jǐ River, and the raccoon dog perishes if it crosses the Wèn—such is the nature of the land’s *qi*.

Yet though their forms and *qi* differ, their natures remain the same; none may alter another. All things preserve their wholeness in life, their sufficiency in portion. How then do I discern their greatness or smallness? Their length or brevity? Their sameness or difference?

The Twin Mountains, Great Shape and Kingly Terrace, span seven hundred *li* in breadth and rise ten thousand *rèn* in height. They once stood south of Jìzhōu and north of Héyáng. There lived an old man of the Northern Mountains, nearly ninety years of age, who dwelt facing them. Vexed by the blockage to the north and the circuitous paths it forced, he gathered his household to deliberate:

“Let us join our strength to level this perilous terrain, carving a passage south to Yù and onward to the southern bank of the Hàn—would this not be good?”

All assented with one voice. His wife, however, raised a doubt: “With your strength, you cannot even reduce the mound of Kuífù—how then will you move Great Shape and Kingly Terrace? And where will you put the earth and stones?”

The others replied: “We shall cast them into the far reaches of the Eastern Sea, north of Yǐntǔ.”

Thereupon, he led his sons and grandsons—three men strong enough to bear the load—striking stone and tilling soil, hauling the debris in baskets to the edge of the Eastern Sea. A widow from the neighboring Jīngchéng clan had a fatherless boy, just old enough to carry himself, who leapt to join their labor. Winter and summer turned, and only then did they make a single return journey.

chunks.original_text: 河曲智叟笑而止之，曰：甚矣汝之不慧。 以残年余力，曾不能毁山之一毛，其如土石何？ 北山愚公长息曰：汝心之固，固不可彻，曾不若孀妻弱子，虽我之死，有子存焉。 子又生#13孙，孙又生子，子又生子，子又生孙，子子孙孙，无穷匮也。 而山不加增，何若而不平？ 河曲智叟亡以应。 操蛇之神闻之，惧其不已也，告之於帝。 帝感其诚，命夸娥氏二子负二山，一厝朔东，一厝雍南。 自此，冀之南、汉之阴无陇断焉。 夸父不量力，欲追日影，逐之於隅谷之际。 渴欲得饮，赴饮河、渭。 河、渭不足，将走北饮大泽。 未至，道渴而死。 弃其杖，尸膏肉所浸，生邓林。 邓林弥广数千里焉。 大禹曰：六合之间，四海之内，照之以日月，经之以星辰，纪之以四时，要之以太岁。 神灵所生，其物其形，或夭或寿，唯圣人能通其道。 夏革曰：然则亦有不待神灵而生，不待阴阳而形，不待日月而明，不待杀戮而夭，不待将迎而寿，不待五谷而食，不待缯纩而衣，不待舟车而行，其道自然，非圣人之所通也。 禹之治水土也，迷而失涂，谬之一国。 滨北海之北，不知距齐州几千万里。 其国名曰终北，不知际畔之所齐限。 无风雨霜露，不生鸟兽、虫鱼、草木之类。 四方悉平，周以乔陟。 当国之中有山，山名壶领，状若甔甀。 顶有口，状若贠环，名曰滋穴。 有水涌出，名曰神瀵，臭过兰椒，味过醪醴。 一源分为四埒，注於山下。 经营一国，亡不悉徧。 土气和，亡札厉。 人性婉而从物，不竞不争，柔心而弱骨，不骄不忌； 长幼侪居，不君不臣； 男女杂游，不媒不聘； 缘水而居，不耕不稼； 土气温适，不织不衣； 百年而死，不夭不病。 其民孳阜亡数，有喜乐，亡衰老哀苦。 其俗好声，相携而迭谣，终日不辍音，饥倦则饮神瀵，力志和平。 过则醉，经旬乃醒。 沐浴神瀵，肤色脂泽，香气经旬乃歇。 周穆王北游过其国，三年忘归。 既反周室，慕其国，撒然自失。 不进酒肉，不召嫔御者，数月乃复。 管仲勉齐桓公因游辽口，俱之其国，几克举。 隰朋谏曰：君舍齐国之广，人民之众，山川之观，殖物之阜，礼义之盛，章服之美，妖靡盈庭，忠良满朝，肆叱则徒卒百万，视撝则诸侯从命，亦奚羡於彼而弃齐国之社稷，从戎夷之国乎？ 此仲父之耄，奈何从之？ 桓公乃止，以隰明之言告管仲。 仲曰：此固非朋之所及也。 臣恐彼国之不可知#14之也。 齐国之富奚恋？ 隰朋之言奚顾？ 南国之人祝发而裸，北国之人鞨际巾而裘，中国之人冠冕而裳。 九土所资，或农或商，或田或渔； 如冬裘夏葛，水舟陆车，默而得之，性而成之。 越之东有辄休之国，其长子生，则鲜而食之，谓之宜弟。 其大父死，负其大母而弃之，曰：鬼妻不可与同居处。 楚之南有炎人之国，其亲戚死，朽与呙同其肉而弃之，然后埋其骨，乃成为孝子。 秦之西有仪渠文康之国者，其亲戚死，聚柴积而焚之。 熏则烟上，谓之登遐，然后成为孝子。 此上而为政，下以为俗，而未足为异也。 孔子东游，见两小儿辨斗，问其故。 一儿曰：我以日始出时去人近，而日中时远也。 一儿以日初出远，而日中时近也。 一儿曰：日初出大如车盖，及日中，则如盘盂，此不为远者小而近者大乎？

The River Bend sage laughed and tried to stop him, saying: “How foolish you are! With your waning years and remaining strength, you cannot even strip a single blade of grass from the mountain—what then can you do with earth and stone?”

North Mountain Foolish Old Man sighed deeply and replied: “Your heart is so rigid it cannot be pierced—you are not even the equal of a widow or a weak child. Though I die, I have sons who survive. Sons beget grandsons, grandsons beget sons, sons again beget sons, sons again beget grandsons—sons and grandsons without end. Yet the mountains do not grow larger. Why then should they not be leveled?”

The River Bend sage had no answer. The spirit who wields the serpent heard of this and, fearing he would never cease, reported it to the Emperor. Moved by his sincerity, the Emperor commanded the two sons of Kuafu to bear the two mountains—one placed east of Shuò, the other south of Yōng. From that time on, south of Jì and north of the Hàn, there were no more ridges to block the way.

Kuafu, overestimating his strength, sought to chase the sun’s shadow and pursued it to the edge of Yú Valley. Thirsting for drink, he rushed to the Yellow River and the Wèi. When the Yellow River and the Wèi proved insufficient, he set off north to drink from the Great Marsh. Before he arrived, he died of thirst along the way. He cast aside his staff, and where his flesh and fat soaked the ground, the Dèng Forest grew. The Dèng Forest spread wide for thousands of *li*.

Great Yǔ said: “Within the Six Directions and the Four Seas, all is illumined by sun and moon, ordered by the stars, marked by the four seasons, and bound by the Great Year. The beings born of spirits and gods, their forms and natures—whether short-lived or long—only the sage can fathom their Dao.”

Xià Gé replied: “Yet there are those who arise without relying on spirits, take form without depending on yin and yang, shine without needing sun and moon, die young without violence, live long without care, eat without grain, clothe themselves without silk or floss, travel without boats or chariots. Their Dao is natural—beyond even the sage’s comprehension.”

When Yǔ governed the waters and lands, he became lost and strayed into a foreign realm. By the northern shore of the Northern Sea, beyond countless thousands of *li* from Qí Province, lay a land called Zhōngběi, its borders and limits unknown. No wind or rain, frost or dew fell there, nor did birds, beasts, insects, fish, grasses, or trees grow. All was level, encircled by towering ridges. At the land’s center stood a mountain named Húlǐng, shaped like an overturned jar. At its summit was an opening, round like a ring, called the Nourishing Cavern. Water gushed forth, named the Divine Spring, its fragrance surpassing orchid and pepper, its taste finer than fine wine. From this single source, four channels flowed down the mountain, irrigating the entire land without exception. The earth’s qi was harmonious, and no plagues or epidemics arose.

The people were gentle and compliant, neither competitive nor contentious, soft-hearted and weak-boned, neither arrogant nor envious. Young and old dwelled together without rulers or subjects; men and women mingled freely without matchmakers or betrothals. They lived along the water, neither plowing nor sowing. The earth’s qi was warm and agreeable, so they neither wove nor wore clothes. They lived a hundred years without dying young or falling ill. Their population flourished without count, ever joyful, never aging or sorrowful.

Their custom was to love music. They linked hands and sang in turns, their voices never ceasing all day. When hungry or weary, they drank from the Divine Spring, their strength and spirits harmonious. If they overindulged, they became drunk, waking only after ten days. Bathing in the Divine Spring, their skin grew sleek and glossy, their fragrance lingering for ten days.

King Mù of Zhōu traveled north and passed through their land, remaining three years before remembering to return. Once back in his court, he longed for that country, lost in melancholy. He refused wine and meat, summoned no concubines, and only after several months did he recover.

Guǎn Zhòng urged Duke Huán of Qí to journey to Liáokǒu, intending to reach that land together. They nearly succeeded, but Xí Péng admonished: “Why abandon Qí’s vast lands, its teeming people, its scenic mountains and rivers, its fertile resources, its flourishing rites and justice, its splendid robes and ornaments? Your halls overflow with beauty, your court with loyal ministers. With a shout, a million soldiers answer; with a gesture, the feudal lords obey. Why envy that land and forsake Qí’s altars of soil and grain to follow barbarians?”

Duke Huán desisted, relaying Xí Péng’s words to Guǎn Zhòng. Guǎn Zhòng replied: “This is beyond Péng’s understanding. I fear that land cannot be known.” Why cling to Qí’s wealth? Why heed Xí Péng’s words?

Among the southern peoples, some shave their heads and go bare; in the north, they wear fur hats and robes; in the Central States, they don crowns and skirts. Across the Nine Provinces, some farm, some trade, some hunt, some fish—like winter furs and summer linen, boats for water and carts for land, all obtained naturally, shaped by nature.

East of Yuè lies the nation of Zhéxiū, where the eldest son is butchered and eaten at birth, called “favoring the younger brother.” When a grandfather dies, they carry the grandmother away and abandon her, saying: “A ghost-wife cannot dwell with the living.”

South of Chǔ lies the land of the Yán people. When kin die, they rot the flesh with maggots, share it among themselves, then discard it before burying the bones—only then are they deemed filial.

West of Qín lies the nation of Yíqú Wénkāng. When kin die, they pile firewood and burn the body. The rising smoke is called “ascending to the distant,” and only then are they deemed filial. Such practices, whether imposed by rulers or adopted as custom, are hardly strange.

Confucius traveled east and saw two children arguing. When he asked the reason, one child said: “I believe the sun is nearer at dawn and farther at noon.”

The other child said: “I believe the sun is farther at dawn and nearer at noon.”

The first child said: “At dawn, the sun is as large as a carriage canopy, but by noon, it is only the size of a plate or bowl. Is this not proof that what is far appears small, and what is near appears large?”

chunks.original_text: 一儿曰：日初出则沧沧凉凉，及其日中如探汤，此不为近者热而远者凉乎？ 孔子不能决也。 两小儿笑曰：孰为汝多知乎？ 均，天下之至理也，连於形物亦然。 均发均县，轻重而发绝，发不均也。 均也，其绝也莫绝。 人以为不然，自有知其然者也。 詹何以独茧丝为纶，芒针为钩，荆莜为竿，剖粒为饵，引盈车之鱼於百仞之渊，汨流之中，纶不绝，钩不伸，竿不挠。 楚王闻而异之，召问其故。 詹何曰：臣闻先大夫之言，蒲且子之弋也，弱弓纤缴，乘风振之，连双鸧於青云之际。 用心专，动手均也。 臣因其事，放而学钓，五年始尽其道。 当臣之临河持竿，心无杂虑，唯鱼之念，投纶沈钓，手无轻重，物莫能乱。 鱼见臣之钩饵，犹沈埃聚沫，吞之不疑。 所以能以弱制强，以轻致重也。 大王治国诚能若此，则天下可运於一握，将亦奚事哉？ 楚王曰：善。 鲁公扈、赵齐婴二人有疾，同请扁鹊求治。 扁鹊治之。 既同愈。 谓公扈、齐婴曰：汝曩之所疾，自外而干府藏者，固药石之所已。 今有偕生之疾，与体偕长。 今为汝攻之，何如？ 二人曰：愿先闻其验。

One child said: "At dawn, the sun is cool and refreshing, but by noon, it is scalding like boiling water—is this not proof that what is near is hot and what is far is cool?"

Confucius could not decide between them.

The two children laughed and said: "Who says you are so wise?"

Uniformity is the supreme principle of the world, and this holds even for physical things. When a hair is uniformly suspended, it will break under the slightest weight if the tension is uneven. Yet if truly uniform, it will not break at all. Others may doubt this, but there are those who know it to be so.

Zhān Hé used a single silkworm’s thread for his line, a needle’s barb for his hook, a stalk of thorny bramble for his rod, and a split grain for his bait. With these, he drew fish as large as a cart from an abyss a hundred *ren* deep, in the midst of rushing currents—yet his line did not snap, his hook did not straighten, and his rod did not bend.

The King of Chǔ, hearing of this, found it extraordinary and summoned him to ask the reason. Zhān Hé replied: "I once heard my late master say that when Pú Jūzǐ went fowling, he used a weak bow and a fine thread, riding the wind to send his arrow aloft, striking two cormorants in the blue sky. His success came from focused intent and balanced movement. I took his example and applied it to fishing, spending five years mastering the Way. When I stand by the river with my rod, my mind is free of distractions, fixed only on the fish. I cast my line and lower my hook with a hand that knows no lightness or heaviness, so nothing can disturb me. To the fish, my hook and bait seem no more than sinking dust or floating foam—they swallow it without hesitation. This is how the weak overcomes the strong, and the light achieves the heavy.

"If Your Majesty governs the state with such focus and balance, the realm could be held in the palm of your hand—what further effort would be needed?"

The King of Chǔ said: "Well said."

Two men, Gōng Yù of Lǔ and Qí Yīng of Zhào, fell ill and together sought treatment from Biǎn Què. After Biǎn Què cured them, he said to Gōng Yù and Qí Yīng: "Your past illnesses, which entered from outside to afflict the organs, were naturally cured by medicine and stone needles. But now you have an illness that has grown with your bodies since birth. If I were to treat this for you, what would you say?"

The two replied: "We would first like to hear the signs."

Confucius traveled east and saw two children arguing. When he asked the reason, one child said: “I believe the sun is nearer at dawn and farther at noon.”

The other child said: “I believe the sun is farther at dawn and nearer at noon.”

The first child said: “At dawn, the sun is as large as a carriage canopy, but by noon, it is only the size of a plate or bowl. Is this not proof that what is far appears small, and what is near appears large?”

chunks.original_text: 扁鹊谓公扈曰：汝志强而气弱，故足於谋而寡於断。 齐婴志弱而气强，故少於虑而伤於专。 若换汝之心，则均於善矣。 扁鹊遂饮二人毒酒，迷死三日，剖胸探心，易而置之，投以神药，既悟如初。 二人辞归。 於是公扈反齐婴之室，而有其妻子，妻子弗识。 齐婴亦反公扈之室，有其妻子，妻子亦弗识。 二室因相与讼，求辨於扁鹊。 扁鹊辨其所由，讼乃已。 瓠巴鼓琴而鸟舞鱼跃。 郑师文闻之，弃家从师襄游。 柱指钧弦，三年不成章。 师襄曰：子可以归矣。 师文舍其琴，叹曰：文非弦之不能钧，非章之不能成。 文所存者不在弦‘，所志者不在声。 内不得於心，外不应於气，故不敢发手而动弦。 且小假之，以观其后。 无几何，复见师襄。 师襄曰：子之琴何如？ 师文曰：得之矣。 请尝试之。
chunks.translated_text:
Bian Que said to Gong Yu: "Your will is strong but your qi is weak, so you excel in planning yet falter in decision. Qi Ying’s will is weak but his qi is strong, so he lacks foresight yet acts with reckless force. If I were to exchange your hearts, you would both attain balance in goodness."

Thereupon, Bian Que gave the two men a poisoned wine to drink, rendering them unconscious for three days. He then opened their chests, extracted their hearts, swapped them, and restored them with a divine medicine. When they awoke, they were as before.

The two men took their leave and returned home. Gong Yu, however, went to Qi Ying’s house and claimed his wife and children, but they did not recognize him. Likewise, Qi Ying went to Gong Yu’s house and took possession of his wife and children, yet they too did not recognize him. The two households then brought their dispute before Bian Que to adjudicate. Bian Que explained the cause, and the dispute was resolved.

When Hu Ba played the zither, birds danced and fish leapt. Zheng Shiwen, hearing of this, abandoned his home to study under Master Xiang. For three years, his fingers pressed the strings and hooked the notes, yet he could not form a single melody. Master Xiang said: "You may return home now."

Shiwen set down his zither and sighed: "It is not that my fingers cannot hook the strings, nor that I cannot form a melody. What I seek does not lie in the strings, nor does my aspiration rest in sound. If within I am not settled in my heart, and without I do not harmonize with qi, I dare not lift my hand to move the strings. Grant me a little more time to see what comes of it."

Before long, he returned to Master Xiang. The master asked: "How is your zither playing now?"

Shiwen replied: "I have grasped it. Allow me to demonstrate."

chunks.original_text: 於是当春而叩商弦以召南吕，冻风忽至，草木成实。 及秋而叩角弦以激夹锺，温风徐回，草木发荣。 当夏而叩羽弦以召黄锺，霜雪交下，川池暴冱。 及冬而叩征弦以激羹宾，阳光炽烈，坚冰立散。 将终，命宫而总四弦，则景风翔，庆云浮，甘露降，澧泉涌。 师襄乃抚心高蹈曰：微矣，子之弹也。 虽师旷之清角，邹衍之吹律，亡以加之，彼将挟琴执管而从子之后耳。 薛谭学讴於秦青，未穷青之技，自谓尽之，遂辞归。 秦青弗止。 饯於郊衢，抚节悲歌，声振林木，响遏行云。 薛谭乃谢求反，终身不敢言归。 秦青顾谓其友曰：昔韩娥东之齐，匮粮，过雍门，鬻歌假食。 既去而余音绕梁欐，三日不绝，左右以其人弗去。 过逆旅，逆旅人辱之。 韩娥因曼声哀哭，一里老幼悲愁，垂涕相对，三日不食。 遽而追之。 娥还，复为曼声长歌。 一里老幼喜跃抃舞，弗能自禁，忘向之悲也。 乃厚赂发之。 故雍门之人至今善歌哭，效娥之遗声。 伯牙善鼓琴，锺子期善听。 伯牙鼓琴，志在登高山。 锺子期曰：善哉，峨峨兮若泰山。 志在流水。 锺子期曰：善哉，洋洋兮若江河。 伯牙所念，锺子期必得之。 伯牙游於泰山之阴，卒逢暴雨，止於岩下； 心悲，乃援琴而鼓之。 初为霖雨之操，更造崩山之音。 曲每奏，锺子期辄穷其趣。 伯牙乃舍琴而叹曰：善哉，善哉，子之听夫。 志想象犹吾心也。 吾於何逃声哉？ 周穆王西巡狩，越昆仑，不至弇山。 反还，未及中国，道有献工人名偃师。 穆王荐之，问曰：若有何能？ 偃师曰：臣唯命所试。 然臣已有所造，愿王先观之。 穆王曰：日以俱来，吾与若俱观之。 越日偃师谒见王。 王荐之，曰：若与偕来者何人？ 对曰：臣之所造能倡者。 穆王惊视之，趣步俯仰，信人也，巧夫镇其颐，则歌合律； 捧其乎，则舞应节。 千变万化。 唯意所适。

At this, he struck the *shang* string in spring to summon *Nanlü*, and suddenly a freezing wind arose, causing grasses and trees to bear fruit. When autumn came, he struck the *jiao* string to rouse *Jiazhong*, and a warm breeze gently swirled, making grasses and trees flourish. In summer, he plucked the *yu* string to invoke *Huangzhong*, and frost and snow fell together, while rivers and ponds froze solid. When winter arrived, he struck the *zhi* string to excite *Rui Bin*, and the sun’s rays blazed fiercely, melting hard ice in an instant.

As the piece neared its end, he commanded the *gong* string to unite the four, and at once a balmy breeze soared, auspicious clouds floated, sweet dew descended, and fragrant springs welled forth. Master Xiang then clapped his chest and leapt in joy, exclaiming: "How subtle is your playing, my student! Even the *Qingjiao* of Master Kuang or the pitch-pipes of Zou Yan could not surpass it—those masters would clutch their zithers and flutes to follow in your wake."

Xue Tan studied singing under Qin Qing, but before mastering his teacher’s art, he claimed to have learned it all and took his leave to return home. Qin Qing did not stop him. At the crossroads outside the city, he gave a farewell feast, beating time and singing a mournful song. His voice shook the trees, and its resonance halted the passing clouds. Xue Tan then begged forgiveness and asked to return, swearing never to speak of leaving again. Qin Qing turned to his friends and said:

"Long ago, Han E traveled east to Qi, but her provisions ran out. Passing through Yongmen, she sold her songs to beg for food. After she left, her lingering notes coiled around the beams for three days without fading, and those nearby felt as though she had not departed. When she stayed at an inn, the innkeeper insulted her. Han E then let forth a drawn-out, sorrowful cry, and the elders and children of the village grieved together, weeping face to face for three days without eating. They hastily pursued her. When Han E returned, she sang a long, melodious song, and the villagers leapt and danced for joy, unable to contain themselves, forgetting their former sorrow. Thus they richly rewarded her and sent her on her way. To this day, the people of Yongmen excel in singing and weeping, imitating Han E’s lingering tones."

Boyi was skilled at playing the zither, and Zhong Ziqi was skilled at listening. When Boyi played with his mind set on climbing a high mountain, Zhong Ziqi said: "How fine! Lofty as Mount Tai!" When his intent turned to flowing water, Zhong Ziqi said: "How fine! Vast as the Yangtze and Yellow River!" Whatever Boyi conceived, Zhong Ziqi always grasped it.

Once, Boyi was traveling along the northern slope of Mount Tai when he was suddenly caught in a violent storm. Taking shelter beneath a cliff, his heart filled with sorrow, and he took up his zither to play. First he composed a piece for ceaseless rain, then shifted to the sound of crumbling mountains. With each melody, Zhong Ziqi exhausted its meaning. Boyi then set down his zither and sighed: "How excellent, how excellent is your listening! Your thoughts and imaginings are as my own heart. Where could I hide my music from you?"

King Mu of Zhou went on a western expedition, crossing the Kunlun Mountains but not reaching Yan Mountain. On his return journey, before reaching the Central States, someone along the way presented a craftsman named Yanshi. The king summoned him and asked: "What skills do you possess?" Yanshi replied: "I will do whatever Your Majesty commands. However, I have already made something I wish you to see first." The king said: "Come with it tomorrow, and we shall view it together."

The next day, Yanshi was granted an audience. The king summoned him and asked: "Who is this person accompanying you?" He replied: "This is my creation, one who can perform." The king stared in astonishment: it walked, bowed, and raised its head—truly human. When the craftsman pressed its chin, it sang in perfect tune; when he held its hand, it danced in perfect rhythm. Its transformations were endless, following every whim.

chunks.original_text: 王以为实人也，与盛姬内御并观之。 技将终，倡者瞬其目而招王之左右侍妾。 王大怒，立欲诛偃师。 偃师大慑，立剖散倡者以示王皆传会革、木、胶、漆、白、黑、丹、青之所为。 王谛料之，内则肝胆、心肺、脾肾、肠胃，外则筋骨、支节、皮毛、齿发、皆假物也，而无不毕具者。 合会复如初见。 王试废其心，则口不能言； 废其肝，则目不能视； 废其肾，则足不能步。 穆王始悦而叹曰：人之巧乃可与造化者同功乎？ 诏贰车载之以归。 夫班输之云梯，墨翟之飞鸢，自谓能之极也。 弟子东门贾、禽滑厘闻偃饰之巧以告二子，二子终身不敢语艺，而时执规矩。 甘蝇，古之善射者，壳弓而兽伏鸟下。 弟子名飞卫，学射於甘蝇，而巧过其师。 纪昌者，又学射於飞卫。 飞卫曰：尔先学不瞬，而后可言射矣。 纪昌归，偃外其妻之机下，以自承牵挺，二年之后，虽锥末倒眦，而不瞬也，以告飞卫。 飞卫曰：未也，必#15学视而后可。 视小如大，视微如着，而后告我。 昌以牦悬虱於牖，南面而望之。 旬日之间，浸大也； 三年之后，如车轮焉。 以睹余物，皆丘山也。 乃以燕角之弧、朔蓬之簳射之，贯虱之心，而悬不绝，以告飞卫。 飞卫高蹈拊膺曰：汝得之矣。 纪昌既尽卫之术，计天下之敌己者，一人而已，乃谋杀飞卫。 相遇於野，二人交射，中路矢锋相触，而坠於地，而尘不扬。 飞卫之矢先穷。 纪昌遗一矢，既发，飞卫以棘刺之端扞之，而无差焉。 於是二子泣而投弓，相拜於涂，请为父子，克臂以誓，不得告术於人。 造父之师曰泰豆氏。 造父之始从习御也，执礼甚卑； 泰豆三年不告。 造父执礼愈谨，乃告之曰：古诗言，良弓之子，必先为箕； 良冶之子，必先为裘。 汝先观吾趣。 趣如吾，然后六辔可持，六马可御。 造父曰：唯命所从。 泰豆乃立木为涂，仅可容足； 计步而置，履之而行。 趣走往还，无跌失也。 造父学之，三日尽其巧。 泰豆叹曰：子何其敏也？ 得之捷乎。 凡所御者，亦如此也。

The king believed it to be a real person and, together with Lady Sheng and his inner attendants, observed its performance. As the act neared its end, the performer winked its eye and beckoned to the king’s concubines on either side. Enraged, the king immediately ordered Yanshi’s execution. Trembling in fear, Yanshi at once dismantled the performer before the king, revealing it to be an assemblage of leather, wood, glue, lacquer, white, black, red, and blue pigments. The king examined it closely: within were liver, gallbladder, heart, lungs, spleen, kidneys, intestines, and stomach; without were sinews, bones, joints, skin, hair, teeth, and hair—all artificial, yet none missing. When reassembled, it appeared as before. The king then tested it: removing its heart, its mouth could not speak; removing its liver, its eyes could not see; removing its kidneys, its feet could not walk. Only then did King Mu smile in wonder and exclaim, "Can human skill truly rival the work of creation?" He ordered a secondary chariot to carry it back.

As for Lu Ban’s cloud ladder and Mo Di’s flying kite, they had deemed their craftsmanship unsurpassable. Yet when their disciples Dongmen Jia and Qin Guli heard of Yanshi’s artistry, they reported it to their masters. From that day forth, the two never dared speak of their skills again, but instead constantly wielded compass and square.

Gan Ying, an ancient master archer, could draw his bow and cause beasts to crouch and birds to descend. His disciple Fei Wei, who studied under Gan Ying, surpassed his teacher in skill. Another disciple, Ji Chang, in turn learned archery from Fei Wei. Fei Wei instructed him, "First master the art of not blinking, then we may speak of archery." Ji Chang returned home and lay beneath his wife’s loom, fixing his gaze upon the suspended treadle. After two years, even when a needle’s tip brushed his eyelashes, he did not blink. He reported this to Fei Wei, who said, "Not yet. You must next learn to see—see the small as large, the faint as distinct—then come tell me." Ji Chang hung a louse from the window with a yak hair and faced south to observe it. Within ten days, it seemed to grow larger; after three years, it appeared as big as a cartwheel. All else he beheld seemed like mountains and hills. He then took a bow of Yan horn and an arrow of northern reed, shot the louse, and pierced its heart without breaking the hair. He told Fei Wei, who leapt up, clapped his chest, and cried, "You have mastered it!"

After Ji Chang had fully learned Fei Wei’s techniques, he calculated that in all the world, only one man could rival him. He plotted to kill Fei Wei. They met in the wild, and the two exchanged arrows. Midway, their arrowheads clashed and fell to the ground without stirring dust. Fei Wei’s arrows were exhausted first. Ji Chang loosed one final arrow, but Fei Wei deflected it with the tip of a thorn, missing not a hair. Thereupon, the two wept, cast aside their bows, bowed to each other on the road, and pledged to become father and son. They swore an oath, cutting their arms, never to teach their art to another.

Zaofu’s master was named Taidou. When Zaofu first began learning charioteering, he observed the rites with utmost humility, yet Taidou did not instruct him for three years. Zaofu’s reverence only deepened, until Taidou finally said, "An ancient poem says, ‘The son of a fine bowyer must first weave baskets; the son of a fine smelter must first sew furs.’ First observe my steps. When you can move as I do, then you may hold the six reins and drive the six horses." Zaofu replied, "I shall follow your command." Taidou then set up a path of wooden planks, just wide enough for his feet, measured in steps and laid out. He walked upon it, running back and forth without stumbling. Zaofu learned this in three days, mastering its skill. Taidou sighed, "How quick you are! You have grasped it swiftly. All charioteering is like this."

chunks.original_text: 曩汝之行，得之於足，应之於心。 推於御也，齐辑乎辔衔之际，而急缓乎唇吻之和； 正度於胸臆之中，而执节乎掌握之间。 内得於中心，而外合於马志，是故能进退履绳而旋曲中规矩，取道致远而气力有余，诚得其术也。 得之於衔，应之於辔，得之于辔，应之於手； 得之於手，应之於心。 则不以目视，不以策驱，,心闲体正，六辔不乱，而二十四蹄所投无差，回旋进退，莫不中节。 然后舆轮之外可使无余辙，马蹄之外可使无余地； 未尝觉山谷之崄，原阳之夷，视之一也。 吾术穷矣，汝其识之。 魏黑卵以昵嫌杀丘邴章。 丘邴章之子来丹谋报父之雠。 丹气其猛，形甚露，计粒而食，顺风而趣，虽怒，不能称兵以报之，耻假力於人，誓手剑以屠黑卵。 黑卵悍志绝众，力抗百夫。 筋骨皮肉非人类也。 延颈承刃，披胸受矢，铓锷推屈，而体无痕挞。 负其才力，视来丹犹雏谷也。 来丹之友申他曰：子怨黑卵至矣，黑卵之易子过矣，将奚谋焉？ 来丹垂涕曰：愿子为我谋。 申他曰：吾闻卫孔周其祖得殷帝之宝剑，一童子服之，却三军之众，奚不请焉？ 来丹遂适卫，见孔周，执仆御之礼，请先纳妻子，后言所欲。 孔周曰：吾有三剑； 唯子所择，皆不能杀人，且先言其状。 一曰含光，视之不可见，运之不知其有。 所触也，泯然无际，经物而物不觉。 二曰承影，将旦昧爽之交，日一夕昏明之际，北面而察之，淡淡焉若有物存，莫识其状。 其所触也，窃窃焉有声，经物而物不疾也。 三日宵练，方昼则见影而不见光，方夜见光而不见形。 其触物也，马善然而过，随过随合，觉疾而不血刃焉。 此三宝者，传之十三世矣，而无施於事，匣而藏之，未尝启封。 来丹曰：虽然，吾必请其下者。 孔周乃归其妻子，与斋七日。 晏阴之间，跪而授其下剑，来丹再拜受之以归。 来丹遂执剑从黑卵。 时黑卵之醉偃牖下，自颈至腰三斩之。 黑卵不觉。 来丹以黑卵之死，趣而退。 遇黑卵之子於门，击之三下，如投虚。 黑卵之子方笑曰：汝何蚩而三招予？ 来丹知剑之不能杀人也，叹而归。 黑卵既醒，怒其妻曰：醉而露我，使我嗌疾而腰急。 其子曰：畴昔来丹之来，遇我於门，三招我，亦使我体疾而支强，彼其厌我哉。 周穆王大征西戎，西戎献锟铻之剑，火浣之布。 其剑长尺有咫，练钢赤刃，用之切玉如切泥焉。 火浣之布，浣之必投於火； 布则火色，垢则布色； 出火而振之，皓然疑乎雪。 皇子以为无此物，传之者妄。 萧叔曰：皇子果於自信，果於诬理哉。 冲虚至德真经卷中竟 #1王：原作『五』，据北宋本改。 #2寤：原作『寝』，据北宋本改。 #3常：北宋本作『当』。 #4国：原本无，据北宋本增。 #5昔：原作『者』，据北宋本改。 #6亡：北宋本作『止』。 #7疾：北宋本作『庶』。 #8於一家：北宋本作『其一道』。 #9之鸣：北宋本作『于马』。 #10为：北宋本无。 #11步：北宋本作『千』。 #12千：北宋本作『十』。 #13生：北宋本作『有』。 #14知：原作『升』，据北宋本改。 #15必：原作『业』据北宋本改。 冲虚至德真经卷下 力命第六

In your former practice, you grasped it with your feet and responded with your heart. Extending this to charioteering, you harmonize the reins and bits with perfect accord, adjusting swiftness and slowness to the harmony of the lips and tongue. You establish the proper measure within your breast and hold the rhythm in your grasp. Internally, you attain it in your center, and externally, you align with the horse’s will. Thus, you can advance and retreat as if treading a cord, turn and curve as if compass-drawn, traverse great distances with energy to spare—truly, you have mastered the art.

You grasp it in the bit and respond with the reins; you grasp it in the reins and respond with your hands; you grasp it in your hands and respond with your heart. Then, without relying on your eyes or urging with the whip, your mind is at ease, your body upright, the six reins unconfused, and the twenty-four hooves land without error. In turning, advancing, or retreating, nothing fails to meet the rhythm. Thereafter, beyond the wheels of your chariot, no trace of tracks remains; beyond the hooves of your horses, no ground is left untouched. You will never perceive the peril of mountains and valleys or the flatness of plains and open land—they will all appear as one. My art is exhausted; remember it well.

Wei Hei’luan, on account of a private grudge, killed Qiu Bingzhang. Bingzhang’s son, Lai Dan, plotted to avenge his father’s death. Lai Dan’s qi was fierce, his form exposed; he ate by counting grains and moved with the wind. Though enraged, he could not wield weapons to exact revenge, for he disdained to borrow strength from others. He swore to slaughter Hei’luan with his own hands and sword.

Hei’luan’s ferocity surpassed all others, his strength equal to a hundred men. His sinews, bones, skin, and flesh were not of mortal kind. He would stretch his neck to meet the blade, bare his chest to receive arrows, yet even when the point bent against him, his body bore no mark or wound. Confident in his strength, he regarded Lai Dan as a mere fledgling.

Lai Dan’s friend, Shen Tuo, said, “Your hatred for Hei’luan is profound, and his underestimation of you is excessive. What plan will you devise?” Lai Dan wept and replied, “I beg you to devise one for me.” Shen Tuo said, “I have heard that Kong Zhou of Wei, a descendant of his lineage, possesses a treasured sword from the Yin emperor. When a mere youth wore it, he repelled the armies of three hosts. Why not seek it from him?”

Lai Dan then went to Wei and met Kong Zhou, serving him with the rites of a charioteer. He first offered his wife and children as collateral, then stated his desire. Kong Zhou said, “I have three swords; choose whichever you wish. None can kill a man, but let me first describe their forms.

The first is called *Han Guang* (Containing Light). When you look at it, it cannot be seen; when you wield it, you do not know it is there. Where it touches, it vanishes without boundary, passing through things without their awareness.

The second is called *Cheng Ying* (Bearing Shadow). At the break of dawn, in the mingling of light and dark, or at dusk, in the blending of day and night, if you face north and observe it, faintly, as if something exists, yet its form cannot be discerned. Where it touches, there is a faint sound, passing through things without harming them.

The third is called *Xiao Lian* (Night Silk). In daylight, you see its shadow but not its light; at night, you see its light but not its form. Where it touches, it passes through swiftly, closing instantly behind it, leaving a sensation of speed but no bloodshed.

These three treasures have been passed down for thirteen generations, yet never put to use. They lie sealed in their caskets, never unsealed.” Lai Dan said, “Even so, I must request the lowest of them.”

Kong Zhou then returned Lai Dan’s wife and children and fasted with him for seven days. At dusk, he knelt and presented the lowest sword. Lai Dan bowed twice, received it, and departed.

Lai Dan then took the sword and approached Hei’luan. At that time, Hei’luan was drunk, sprawled beneath a window. Lai Dan struck him three times from neck to waist, yet Hei’luan felt nothing. Taking Hei’luan for dead, Lai Dan hurried away. At the gate, he encountered Hei’luan’s son and struck him three times, as if thrusting into emptiness. Hei’luan’s son laughed and said, “Why are you so foolish as to wave at me thrice?” Lai Dan, realizing the sword could not kill, sighed and returned home.

When Hei’luan awoke, he raged at his wife, “You let me drink until I exposed myself! Now my throat is sore and my waist stiff.” His son said, “Earlier, Lai Dan came and met me at the gate. He waved at me three times, and now my body aches and my limbs are stiff. He must have cast a curse on me!”

King Mu of Zhou launched a great campaign against the Western Rong. The Western Rong presented him with a *Kun Wu* sword and fire-washed cloth. The sword was a foot and a handspan in length, its blade forged of refined steel and glowing red. When used, it cut jade as if it were mud. The fire-washed cloth, when washed, must be cast into fire. The cloth turns the color of flame, while the grime turns the color of the cloth. When removed from the fire and shaken, it gleams as if pure snow.

The Crown Prince believed no such things existed and dismissed the accounts as false. Xiao Shu said, “Your Highness is too certain in your own judgment, too quick to dismiss reason!” *The Central Scroll of the Perfect Dao of Profound Virtue* concludes here.

chunks.original_text: 力谓命曰：若之功奚若我哉？ 命曰：汝奚功於物而欲比朕？ 力曰：寿夭、穷达、贵贱、贫富，我力之所能也。 命曰：彭祖之智，不出尧、舜之上，而寿八百； 颜渊之才，不出众人之下，而寿四八； 仲尼之德，不出诸侯之下，而困於阵、蔡； 殷纣之行，不出三仁之上，而居君位。 季札无爵於昊，田恒专有齐国。 夷、齐饿于首阳，季氏富於展禽。 若是汝力之所能，奈何寿彼而夭此，穷圣而达逆，贱贤而贵愚，贫善而富恶邪？ 力曰：若如是言，我固无功於物，而物若此耶，此则若之所制邪？ 命曰：既谓之命，奈何有制之者邪？ 朕直而推之，曲而任之。 自寿自夭，逢穷自达，自贵自贱，自富自贫。 朕岂能识之哉？ 朕岂能识之哉？

Force said to Fate, “What are your achievements compared to mine?”

Fate replied, “What have you ever done for things that you would compare yourself to me?”

Force said, “Longevity or early death, success or failure, high or low status, wealth or poverty—all these are within my power.”

Fate said, “The wisdom of Peng Zu did not surpass that of Yao or Shun, yet he lived eight hundred years. The talent of Yan Yuan did not fall below that of the common crowd, yet he lived but thirty-two years. The virtue of Confucius did not fall below that of the feudal lords, yet he was besieged between Chen and Cai. The conduct of King Zhou of Yin did not surpass that of the Three Benevolent Ones, yet he occupied the throne. Ji Zha held no rank in Wu, while Tian Heng monopolized the state of Qi. Boyi and Shuqi starved at Shouyang, while the Ji clan grew richer than Zhan Qin. If all these are within your power, why do you grant long life to one and early death to another, thwart the worthy and advance the perverse, debase the wise and exalt the foolish, impoverish the good and enrich the wicked?”

Force said, “If this is so, then I truly have no power over things. Yet if things are as they are, is this not your doing?”

Fate said, “Since it is called Fate, how could there be one who controls it? I merely push forward the straight and let the crooked take their course. Longevity or early death, success or failure, high or low status, wealth or poverty—all arise of themselves. How could I comprehend them? How could I comprehend them?”

chunks.original_text: 北官子谓西门子曰：朕与子并世也，而人子达； 并族也，而人子敬； 并貌也，而人子爱； 并言也，而人子庸； 并行也，而人子诚； 并仕也，而人子贵； 并农也，而人子富； 并商也，而人子利。 朕衣则短褐，食则粢粝称，居则蓬室，出则徒行。 子衣则文#1锦，食则粱肉，居则连欐，山宜切出则结驷。 在家熙然有弃朕之心，在朝夸然有敖朕之色。 请谒不相及，遨游不同行，固有年矣。 子自以德过朕邪？ 西门子曰：予无以知其实。 汝造事而穷，予造事而达，此厚薄之验欤？ 而皆谓与予并，汝之颜厚矣。 北宫子无以应，自失而归。 中涂遇东郭先生。 先生曰：汝奚往而反，偊偊而步，有深愧之色邪？ 北宫子言其状。 东郭先生曰：吾将舍汝之愧，与汝更之西门氏而问之。 曰：汝奚辱北宫子之深乎？ 固且言之。 西门子曰：北宫子言世族、年貌、言行与予并，而贱贵、贫富与予异。 予语之曰：予无以知其实。 汝造事而穷，予造事而达，此将厚薄之验欤？ 而皆谓与予并，汝之颜厚矣。 东郭先生曰：汝之言厚薄、不过言才德之差，吾之言厚薄，异於是矣。 夫北宫子厚於德，薄於命； 汝厚於命，薄於德。 汝之达，非智得也。 北宫子之穷，非愚失也。 皆天也，非人也。 而汝以命厚自矜，北宫子以德厚自愧，皆不识夫固然之理矣。 西门子曰：先生止矣。 予不敢复言。 北宫子既归，衣其短褐，有狐貉之温； 进其茂菽，有稻粱之味，庇其蓬室，若广厦之荫，乘其荜何辂，若文轩之饰。 终身道然，不知荣辱之在彼，在我也。 东郭先生闻之曰：北宫子之寐久矣，一言而能寤，易悟也哉。 管夷吾、鲍叔牙二人相友甚戚，同处於齐。 管夷吾事公子纠，鲍叔牙事公子小白。 齐公族多宠，嫡庶并行。 国人惧乱。 管仲与召忽奉公子纠奔鲁，鲍叔奉公子小白奔莒。 既而公孙无知作乱，齐无君，二公子争入。 管夷吾与小白战於莒，道射中小白带钩#2，小白既立，胁鲁杀子纠，召忽死之，管夷吾被囚。 鲍叔牙谓桓公曰：管夷吾能，可以治国。 桓公曰：我雠也，愿杀之。 鲍叔牙曰：吾闻贤君无私怨，且人能为其主，亦必能为人君。 如欲霸王，非夷吾其弗可。 君必舍之。 遂召管仲。 鲁归之齐，鲍叔牙郊迎，释其囚。 桓公礼之，而位於高、国之上，鲍叔牙以身下之，任以国政，号曰仲父。 桓公遂霸。 管仲尝叹曰：吾少穷困时，尝与鲍叔牙贾，分财多自与； 鲍叔不以我为贪，知我贫也。 吾尝为鲍叔谋事而大穷困，鲍叔不以我为愚，知时有利不利也。 吾尝三仕，三见逐於君，鲍叔不以我为不肖，知我不遭时也。 吾尝三战三北，鲍叔不以我为怯，知我有老母也。 公子纠败，召忽死之，吾幽囚受辱，鲍叔不以我为无耻，知我不羞小节而耻名不显於天下也。 生我者父母，知我者鲍叔也。 此世称管、鲍善交者，小白善用能者。 然实无善交，实无用能也。 实无善交实无用能者，非更有善交，更有善用能也。 召忽非能死，不得不死； 鲍叔非能举贤，不得不举； 小白非能用雠，不得不用。 及管夷吾有病，小白问之，曰：仲父之病病矣，可不讳。 云至於大病，则寡人恶乎属国而可？ 夷吾曰：公谁欲欤？ 小白日：鲍叔牙可。 曰：不可。 其为人，洁廉善士也，其於不已若者不比之人，一闻人之过，终身不忘。

Beigongzi said to Ximenzi, “You and I are of the same generation, yet you are esteemed by others. We belong to the same clan, yet you are respected. We share the same appearance, yet you are beloved. We speak alike, yet your words are heeded. We act alike, yet your conduct is trusted. We both serve in office, yet you are honored. We both till the soil, yet you grow wealthy. We both engage in trade, yet you profit. I wear coarse hemp, eat coarse grain, dwell in a thatched hut, and travel on foot. You wear embroidered brocade, feast on fine millet and meat, reside in a mansion with towering beams, and ride in a carriage drawn by four horses. At home, you are cheerful and seem to scorn me; at court, you are haughty and display contempt for me. You do not seek my favor, nor do we stroll together—this has been so for years. Do you consider your virtue superior to mine?”

Ximenzi replied, “I have no way to know the truth of this. You undertake affairs and fail; I undertake them and succeed. Is this not proof of our differing fates? Yet you claim we are the same—your face is thick indeed.”

Beigongzi had no reply. He departed in dismay.

On the road, he encountered Master Dongguo. The master said, “Where have you been, that you return with such a dejected gait and a look of deep shame?”

Beigongzi recounted what had happened.

Master Dongguo said, “I will relieve your shame. Let us go together to Ximen’s house and question him. Say: ‘Why do you so deeply humiliate Beigongzi?’ Speak plainly.”

Ximenzi said, “Beigongzi claims we share the same generation, clan, age, appearance, speech, and conduct, yet our status and wealth differ. I told him: ‘I have no way to know the truth of this. You undertake affairs and fail; I undertake them and succeed. Is this not proof of our differing fates? Yet you claim we are the same—your face is thick indeed.’”

Master Dongguo said, “Your notion of ‘fate’ refers only to differences in talent and virtue. My notion of ‘fate’ is different. Beigongzi is rich in virtue but poor in fate; you are rich in fate but poor in virtue. Your success is not due to wisdom, nor is his failure due to folly. Both are Heaven’s doing, not man’s. Yet you boast of your favorable fate, while Beigongzi feels shame for his virtue—neither of you understands the principle of what is inherently so.”

Ximenzi said, “Enough, Master. I dare not speak further.”

After Beigongzi returned home, he wore his coarse hemp, which was as warm as fox or raccoon fur. He ate his coarse beans, which tasted as fine as rice and millet. He sheltered in his thatched hut, which shaded like a grand hall. He rode in his humble cart, which seemed as ornate as a carved chariot. For the rest of his life, he remained content, unaware of honor or disgrace lying in others rather than himself.

Master Dongguo, hearing of this, said, “Beigongzi has slept for a long time. A single word awakened him—how easily he was enlightened!”

Guan Yiwu and Bao Shuya were close friends, bound by deep affection, and both lived in Qi. Guan Yiwu served Prince Jiu, while Bao Shuya served Prince Xiaobai. The Qi ruling house had many favored sons, with legitimate and illegitimate heirs competing. The people feared chaos. Guan Zhong and Shao Hu escorted Prince Jiu in flight to Lu, while Bao Shuya escorted Prince Xiaobai to Ju. Later, when Duke Wuzhi rebelled and Qi was left without a ruler, the two princes raced to return. Guan Yiwu fought Xiaobai on the road to Ju, shooting an arrow that struck Xiaobai’s belt hook. Once Xiaobai ascended the throne, he pressured Lu to kill Prince Jiu. Shao Hu died for him, while Guan Yiwu was imprisoned.

Bao Shuya said to Duke Huan, “Guan Yiwu is capable—he can govern the state.”

Duke Huan replied, “He is my enemy. I wish to kill him.”

Bao Shuya said, “I have heard that a worthy ruler harbors no personal grudges. Moreover, one who serves his lord faithfully will surely serve his ruler well. If you wish to become a hegemon, you cannot do without Yiwu. You must pardon him.”

Thereupon, Duke Huan summoned Guan Zhong. When Lu returned him to Qi, Bao Shuya welcomed him beyond the city gates and freed him from his bonds. Duke Huan treated him with honor, placing him above Gao and Guo. Bao Shuya humbled himself before him, entrusting him with state affairs and addressing him as “Father Zhong.” Duke Huan thus became a hegemon.

Guan Zhong once sighed, saying, “When I was young and poor, I once traded with Bao Shuya, taking more than my share of the profits. Bao Shuya did not think me greedy, knowing I was impoverished. I once devised a plan for Bao Shuya that led to great failure. He did not think me foolish, knowing that circumstances have their favorable and unfavorable moments. I was employed three times and dismissed three times by my lords. Bao Shuya did not think me worthless, knowing I had not met with the right time. I fought three battles and fled three times. He did not think me cowardly, knowing I had an elderly mother to care for. When Prince Jiu was defeated, Shao Hu died for him, while I was imprisoned and humiliated. Bao Shuya did not think me shameless, knowing I did not scorn minor setbacks but felt shame if my name were not renowned throughout the world. My parents gave me life, but Bao Shuya truly knew me.”

This is why the world praises Guan and Bao for their fine friendship, and Xiaobai for his skill in employing the capable. Yet in truth, there was no fine friendship, nor any skill in employing the capable. There was no fine friendship, no skill in employing the capable—it was not that there was some other fine friendship or skill in employing the capable. Shao Hu did not choose to die; he had no choice but to die. Bao Shuya did not choose to recommend the worthy; he had no choice but to recommend them. Xiaobai did not choose to employ his enemy; he had no choice but to employ him.

When Guan Yiwu fell ill, Xiaobai visited him and said, “Father Zhong’s illness is grave. You must not conceal it. If it becomes critical, to whom should I entrust the state?”

Yiwu asked, “Whom do you wish to appoint?”

Xiaobai said, “Bao Shuya will do.”

Yiwu replied, “He will not do. He is a man of integrity and a fine gentleman. Toward those who are not his equal, he does not associate with them. Once he hears of a person’s faults, he never forgets them for the rest of his life.”

Longevity or early death, success or failure, high or low status, wealth or poverty—all arise of themselves. How could I comprehend them? How could I comprehend them?”

chunks.original_text: 使之理国，上且钩乎君，下且逆乎民。 其得罪於君也，将弗久矣。 小白曰：然则孰可？ 对曰：勿已，则阳朋可。 其为人也，上忘而下不叛，愧其不若黄帝，而哀不已若者。 以德分人，谓之圣人，以财分人，谓之贤人。 以贤临人，未有得人者也； 以贤下人者，未有不得人者也。 其於国有不闻也，其於家有不见也。 勿已，则隰朋可。 然则管夷吾非薄鲍叔也，不得不薄； 非厚隰朋也，不得不厚。 厚之於始，或薄之於终； 或厚之於始。 厚薄之去来．弗由我也。 邓析操两可之说，设无穷之辞，当子产执政，作《竹刑》。 郑国用之，数难子产之治。 子产屈之。 子产执而戮之，俄而诛之。 然则子产非能用《竹刑》，不得不用； 邓析非能屈子产，不得不屈； 子产非能诛邓析，不得不诛也。 可以生#3而天福也； 可以死而死，天福也。 可以生而不生，天罚也； 可以死而不死，天罚也。 可以生，可以死，得生得死，有矣； 不可以生，不可以死，或死或生，有矣。 然而生生死死，非物非我，皆命也。 智之所无奈何。 故曰：窈然无际，天道自会，漠然无分，天道自运。 天地不能犯，圣智不能干，鬼魅不能欺。 自然者默之成之，平之宁之，将之迎之。 杨朱之友曰季梁，季梁得疾，七日大渐。 其子环而泣之，请医。 季梁谓杨朱曰：吾子不肖，如此之甚，汝奚不为我歌以晓之？ 杨朱歌曰：天其弗识，人胡能觉？ 匪佑自天，弗孽由人。 我乎汝乎，其弗知乎？ 医乎巫乎，其知之乎？ 其子弗晓，终谒三医。 一曰矫氏，二曰俞氏，三曰庐氏，诊其所疾。 矫氏谓季梁曰：汝寒温不节，虚实失度，病由饥饱色欲，精虑烦散，非天非鬼。 虽渐，可攻也。 季梁曰：众医也，亟屏之。

If you appoint him to govern the state, above he will entangle his lord, below he will oppose the people. His offense against his lord will not be long in coming.”

Xiaobai said, “Then who will do?”

Yiwu replied, “If you must have someone, then Yang Peng will do. His character is such that above he forgets his lord, below he does not betray the people. He feels shame before those who surpass him like the Yellow Emperor and pities those who fall short of him. To share virtue with others is called a sage; to share wealth with others is called a worthy. To rule others with worth is never to win them; to humble oneself before others with worth is never to fail to win them. In the state, there are things he does not hear; in his household, there are things he does not see. If you must have someone, then Xi Peng will do.”

Yet Guan Yiwu did not slight Bao Shuya—he had no choice but to slight him; nor did he favor Xi Peng—he had no choice but to favor him. To favor at the outset may lead to slighting in the end; to slight at the outset may lead to favoring in the end. The coming and going of favor and slight are not of my doing.

Deng Xi wielded arguments of dual possibility, crafting endless words. When Zichan held office, Deng composed the *Bamboo Penal Code*. The state of Zheng adopted it, repeatedly challenging Zichan’s governance. Zichan yielded to him. Zichan seized and executed him, then shortly after put him to death. Yet Zichan did not choose to use the *Bamboo Penal Code*—he had no choice but to use it; Deng Xi did not choose to yield to Zichan—he had no choice but to yield; Zichan did not choose to execute Deng Xi—he had no choice but to execute him.

To live when one ought to live is Heaven’s blessing; to die when one ought to die is Heaven’s blessing. To live when one ought not to live is Heaven’s punishment; to die when one ought not to die is Heaven’s punishment. To live when one can live, to die when one can die—such cases exist. To be unable to live, unable to die—yet to live or die—such cases exist as well. Yet life and death, life and death, are neither of things nor of the self; all is fate. Where wisdom is powerless, it is said:

“Profound and boundless,
the Dao of Heaven meets of itself;
vast and undivided,
the Dao of Heaven moves of itself.
Neither Heaven nor Earth can transgress it,
neither sages nor wisdom can interfere,
neither ghosts nor spirits can deceive.
That which is natural—silently it completes,
calmly it pacifies,
leading and guiding it.”

Yang Zhu’s friend Ji Liang fell ill, and after seven days, his condition worsened. His sons gathered around weeping and summoned physicians. Ji Liang said to Yang Zhu, “My sons are so unworthy—why do you not sing for them to enlighten them?”

Yang Zhu sang:
“Heaven does not know—
how could man be aware?
Not blessing from Heaven,
not misfortune from man.
I or you—
who understands?
Physician or shaman—
do they know?”

His sons did not understand, so they finally consulted three physicians. The first was named Jiao, the second Yu, and the third Lu. They diagnosed his illness.

Jiao said to Ji Liang, “Your cold and warmth are unregulated, your deficiency and excess are disordered. Your illness arises from hunger and satiety, lust and desire, and the scattering of essence and thought—neither Heaven nor ghosts are to blame. Though grave, it can be treated.”

Ji Liang said, “A common physician,” and promptly dismissed him.
